text: in the early days of AIDS if you were
diagnosed it was a death sentence I'd
see these amazingly beautiful men
reduced to just walking skeletons 1993
was the worst year that was the year
lost most of my friends one hospital
visit to one memorial service to to the
to a funeral to a cremation service to a
hospital visit one after the other after
the other it's hard you know people
don't come for it and I understand why I
didn't come forward for ten years I
lived in absolute fear and horror that I
would be found out those of us who
remember the 1980s still have the scar
emotional scars of the death and the
dying and those scars may have hardened
and healed in some respects but they're
still there one day my roommate showed
me this lump that he had on his shoulder
and you know this is about 1981-82 and I
went with him to the doctor and the
doctor said you have AIDS we didn't
really know what to do what to say and I
said to him well can you give us a
referral and he said there are no
referrals you know are you religious
sometimes you would take him to hospital
they discover that you had AIDS they
didn't want to touch you I mean there
were times when when people would die
and be put in like black garbage bags I
mean these are the sons of people they
were treated like garbage people have a
harder time believing that you can get
HIV from one active unprotected sex in
my case I think it was one maybe two you
know so with a friend a good person
someone
someone I trusted someone who didn't
know that he had it it took me three
years to confirm that I was in fact HIV
positive because I didn't want to know
none of us wanted to know because if you
were hiv-positive it probably meant you
were gonna have AIDS and then die my
boyfriend Michael Gault died of aids
Michael was on the protease lottery his
number wasn't called because it wasn't
approved in 93 his number didn't get
picked he died to me that such shows
what the meds did how if you weren't
lucky enough to have your number called
you died and if you were part of a trial
for the Proteas or lived long enough to
actually be somebody who could just get
it at a pharmacy you started to live I
remember that period we're friends who
looked like they were going to die
suddenly the retroviral drugs started
being available and they went from being
emaciated sick kaposi's everything to
actually clawing their way back into
some kind of functional mode so
hallelujah that was amazing and frankly
had I not been in that early clinical
trial I might not even be here today
there are so many people who didn't make
it and I was right on that cusp of you
know had I been diagnosed a little bit
earlier I might not have made it people
died back then so that others can live
today in those who live today need to
know the sacrifice that those people who
died made in the 80s and the early 90s
so that their sacrifice wasn't in bed
you
